chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect cirrhosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Suspect cirrhosis: 

  • In high risk groups, especially if there are non-specific symptoms such as malaise, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, weight loss, muscle wasting, or abdominal pain.
  • If examination identifies:
    • Palpable left lobe of the liver, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly.
    • The presence of stigmata of chronic liver disease (spider naevi, palmar erythema, white nails, muscle wasting).
    • Features of severe liver impairment and signs of decompensated liver disease, such as:
      • Jaundice (examine the sclera under natural light).
      • Abnormal bruising.
      • Peripheral oedema.
      • Ascites.
      • Sepsis.
      • Variceal bleeding.
      • Encephalopathy (a sign of this is asterixis — sudden involuntary flexion-extension movements of the wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints when the arms are extended, the wrists dorsiflexed, and the eyes closed for at least 30 seconds).
  • If a person is known to have chronic liver disease and has a low platelet count, elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST): alanine transaminase (ALT) ratio, high bilirubin, low albumin, or increased prothrombin time or international normalized ratio (INR).
    • Note that liver function tests may be normal in cirrhosis, so the whole clinical picture should be taken into account. Liver disease should still be considered if other symptoms or signs are present.
    • In a person not known to have liver disease, consider chronic liver disease as a possibilty and investigate if there are persistently abnormal liver blood tests.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Importance of suspecting cirrhosis in primary care

  • Identifying cirrhosis can be difficult, particularly in people with compensated liver disease, and diagnosis is often delayed. Almost half of people with cirrhosis experience no symptoms of liver disease, and liver function tests may be normal or only mildly abnormal. Some people may present with the less specific features of liver disease, for example, fatigue, itch, or loss of appetite [Williams et al, 2014; National Guideline Centre, 2016; Flamm, 2017]. 
    • A UK study found that for people in primary care with abnormal liver function tests, the opportunity to investigate or refer to make a diagnosis was sometimes missed. Of 873 people, 18% were not followed up appropriately, and 11% had abnormal test results that would have likely benefited from hospital follow up [Sherwood et al, 2001].
  • Suspecting cirrhosis is important because the condition may not be recognised in the asymptomatic group until the liver starts to fail [National Guideline Centre, 2016]. By the time symptoms occur it may be harder or even too late to reverse the disease [Flamm, 2017]. Earlier diagnosis of liver disease and cirrhosis increases chances to offer treatment and prevent complications and progression to end-stage liver disease [National Guideline Centre, 2016]. In providing first-contact care, primary healthcare professionals are well-placed to identify people at risk of, or with symptoms of, chronic liver disease and should be observant for the less obvious signs or symptoms to enable an earlier diagnosis to be made and prevent complications [Flamm, 2017]. Expert opinion in a consensus statement and a review article emphasises the key role of primary healthcare practitioners in identifying people with risk factors for, or symptoms of liver disease [Muir, 2015; Shawcross et al, 2016].  

Suspecting cirrhosis in high-risk groups

  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article which discusses the identification of cirrhosis by the targeted screening of high-risk groups [Keane et al, 2016]. The specific risk factors mentioned are in line with the NICE guidance on Cirrhosis in the over 16s: assessment and management [NICE, 2016] and a review of epidemiological data [Blachier, 2013].  
  • The NICE guideline development group noted the lack of a validated risk tool to predict a person's risk of cirrhosis occurring. It was thought that creating such a tool to identify groups requiring further investigation would potentially reduce the chances of progression to end-stage liver disease and avoid complications and the subsequent impact on NHS resources [National Guideline Centre, 2016].  

Suspecting cirrhosis based on examination findings

  • The non-specific symptoms listed reflect expert opinion from the British Liver Trust and Royal College of General Practitioners [British Liver Trust and RCGP, 2017] and CKS has pragmatically suggested these are particularly relevant in people with risk factors based on the increased likelihood of cirrhosis in this group. Other findings that may indicate cirrhosis are based on expert opinion in review articles [Starr and Raines, 2011; Udell et al, 2012; Tsochatzis et al, 2014; Ellul et al, 2015; Muir, 2015; British Liver Trust and RCGP, 2017; Flamm, 2017]. 
  • A literature review to identify clinical indicators to exclude or detect cirrhosis in adults with known or suspected liver disease found that ascites on physical examination increased the likelihood of cirrhosis (likelihood ratio [LR] 7.2, 95% CI 2.9–12), whereas absence of hepatomegaly or a firm liver on examination decreased the likelihood (LR 0.37, 95% CI 0.24–0.51) [Udell et al, 2012].   

Suspecting cirrhosis based on blood test results

  • It is important to bear in mind that liver function tests do not rule out cirrhosis, as they can be surprisingly normal, even in advanced disease [Starr and Raines, 2011; Udell et al, 2012; RCGP, 2017]. 
  • This recommendation is based on a UK consensus Guideline on the management of abnormal liver blood tests, which states that bilirubin, albumin and INR give information about liver function, and platelet count can be indicative of the level of fibrosis [Newsome, 2018]. CKS has also taken into account expert opinion in review articles and expert opinion from reviewers of this CKS topic.
    • Expert opinion in a review article lists elevated AST/ALT ratio as a subtle sign of cirrhosis [Flamm, 2017].
    • The liver is less able to metabolise bilirubin as hepatocyte damage occurs, leading to higher serum levels. Synthesis of proteins (including clotting factors) and transaminases is also adversely affected as hepatocytes are lost. Thrombocytopenia may occur as a result of sequestration in the spleen due to portal hypertension [Starr and Raines, 2011; Muir, 2015]. 
    • Unsuspected cirrhosis is found in 10–17% of people with unexplained aminotransferase elevation [Udell et al, 2012].
